title-group.article-title: Education and Information for Practicing School Nurses
title-group.subtitle: Which Technology-Supported Resources Meet Their Needs?

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Lori S. Anderson, PhD, RN, CPNP, is an assistant professor at the School of Nursing, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI.
Karmin J. Enge, MS, RN, is a nursing informatics specialist at the University of Wisconsin Hospital and Clinics, Madison, WI.

article-meta.aff: 1School of Nursing, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
2University of Wisconsin Hospital and Clinics, Madison, WI, USA

author-notes.corresp: Lori S. Anderson, PhD, RN, CPNP, School of Nursing University of Wisconsin-Madison, 600 Highland Avenue, Madison, WI 53792, USA Email: lsanderson@wisc.edu

abstract.p: School nurses care for children with a variety of health-related conditions and they need information about managing these conditions, which is accessible, current, and useful. The goal of this literature review was to gather and synthesize information on technology-supported resources and to determine which met the educational needs of school nurses. Successful online educational programs were interactive and self-directed. The most common barriers were lack of time to find educational information, lack of knowledge about computers, technology, the Internet and specific programs, and lack of administrative support from school officials to use technology to access information and evidence for practice. Recommendations for successful use of technology to meet practicing school nurse’s educational needs are offered.

body.p: School-age youth increasingly bring a variety of health-related needs into the classroom. The extent to which these needs are met has implications for the child and their family. The school nurse role is critical to the implementation of quality school health services. For many children, contact with a school nurse may be the only consistent access to a health care professional. Optimally prepared school nurses are needed to meet the multiple, complex demands of 21st-century health care in educational settings. Quickly changing technologies, rapidly expanding information, and increasingly complex care requirements have left school nurses seeking the support and further training necessary to provide quality care for children. The school nurse is often the only health professional in an educational setting; other school nurses may be miles away in other districts with little or no contact between them. This is in contrast to nursing professionals in acute care or primary care settings where support and information can be easily obtained from nursing colleagues in the same institution.

School nurses need information about managing health conditions, which is accessible, current, and useful. This information can be offered as separate educational programs or made available when it is needed, or “just in time.” “Just in time” availability of information could occur in a variety of settings and times such as a remote school location, on the playground, or in the middle of a busy lunch hour. The National Association of School Nurses (2011) commented about the importance of educational activities:
The quality of nursing practice is directly linked to the practitioner’s body of knowledge and the level of skills. The availability of national, regional, state and local educational activities related to practicing in the school setting, benefits the school nurse and the children and communities served.

Advances in technology have broadened access to this information. The broadened access can increase support of the school nurse by providing the necessary information to meet diverse needs. The goal of this literature review was to gather and synthesize information on technology-supported resources and to determine which meet the in-depth educational and just-in-time informational needs of school nurses.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: A literature search was performed utilizing the databases, Cumulative Index of Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), PubMed, and the Educational Resources Information Center. The period of review was 1990–2010 with a focus on those articles from 2000 to 2010, keeping in mind that technology changes very quickly and articles older than 10 years may not offer currently relevant information. Only peer-reviewed journals were evaluated. Search terms used were continuing education, school nurs*, technology, Internet, and web-based. This search yielded 42 articles, 29 of which were specific to school nurses and 7 of which were related to continuing education and school nurses. Due to the small number of studies found with the initial terms, the search was expanded to include the terms computer assisted, computer mediated, and multimedia learning. This search yielded 146 articles, of which 19 were related to continuing education, school nurses, and technology. The abstracts were read to identify those research studies that were related to school nurses or nurses in a setting with similar continuing education needs, such as the need for “just in time” learning or the use of technology to meet continuing education needs. In addition, the Journal of School Nursing from 2005 to current was hand searched for studies related to the search terms, yielding one additional article. Summaries of the 19 articles included in this literature review are presented in Table 1.

tr.td: Survey of school nurses
Convenience sample of school nurses 247 surveys 44 states and the District of Columbia
Cross-sectional survey design

Participants rated information sources as follows: conferences 87.3%, continuing education classes 87%, other school nurses 81.6%, and databases lowest at 27.3%. The use of Internet sources (65.5%) were rated greater than textbooks (48.0%). 83% indicated a high level of comfort using the computer for learning, 73% thought computer-based distance learning offered benefits and 56% thought it offered improved convenience over classroom learning
Rogers’ (1962) diffusion of innovation theory
Four types of web-based learning
57 hospital- and community-based registered nurses in Canada
Qualitative-descriptive design with cross-sectional surveys and focus group interviews

Findings reflected some frustration and anxiety that nurses experienced using online education. The majority of nurses did report that the course content was useful, was easy to navigate, and web-based learning was convenient. Major themes and subthemes:1. Knowledge, skills, and comfort with technology 2. Communication and connection with teacher and peers 3. Experiences with the learning environment 4. Adjusting to the role of online learner
Lawton’s (1997) model of supportive learning for distance
Online continuing Education and Blackboard Learning system
19 school nurses in Missouri
Pilot and formative evaluation

Inconclusive for preference of online training vs. face-to-face. Only 4 (33%) preferred the online continuing education program, 6 (50%) were not sure, and 2 (17%) did not prefer online continuing education. Availability of training in technology use is pertinent
Rogers’ (1962) diffusion of innovation theory
On-site and online workshops and Blackboard Learning system
62 School nurses in western Pennsylvania
Post-test and evaluation

Some lessons learned: Importance of collaboration with state and school nurse consultants, collaboration with schools of nursing, make learning appealing, and appreciate varying learning styles. The online course was underutilized and it is suggested that the use of learner-focused strategies may keep the users engaged. Inconclusive for preference to the online learning method
Statewide survey
103 advanced practice nurses in Nevada
Questionnaire

Top three preferences for receiving education were in-person conference, print-based self-study, and interactive video conference. Live satellite conference was least preferred method. The most frequently stated reason for not using either the Internet or CD-ROM was “not knowing how.” A large majority (77%) of respondents indicated interest in receiving instruction to facilitate their use of computers for CE training via the Internet or CD-ROM
Web-based learning
202 Public health nurses (PHN) from Taiwan
Cross-sectional research design. Questionnaire

Nurses presented a preference for web-based learning. Most subjects (91.6%, n = 185) expressed that it was “definitely possible” or “possible” for them to participate in web-based learning program for the purpose of continuing education. PHNs present a moderate degree of perceived usefulness (M = 8.02 of the possible 25; SD = 2.17), perceived ease of use (M = 16.99 of the possible 25; SD = 2.34), and attitude toward web-based learning (M = 16.99 of the possible 25; SD = 2.31)
Technology acceptance model (TAM) proposed by Davis et al. (1989)
Online continuing education
17 Articles for health care professionals including 5 in nursing
Literature review

In-person continuing education was the most frequent and preferred format; however, the use of the Internet for continuing education was increasing. Participants using the Internet for continuing education tended to be younger or more recent graduates. Barriers to use of the Internet for continuing education were expressed as lack of computer competency and technical difficulties
Use of health resources for electronic clinical information
25 Nursing students, with a wide variety of nursing degrees
Questionnaires, interviews, and observations

96% of nursing students used CINAHL, but only 4% of clinical nurses, none of whom had access to CINAHL at work. MEDLINE was used by 40% of nursing students and only 4% of clinical nurses. The National Cancer Institute’s cancer.gov website was used by 24% of nursing students, compared to only 4% of clinical nurses. Some nursing students used NLM’s MedlinePlus (13%), but no clinical nurses did. While 68% of clinical nurses had access to Personal digital assistants (PDAs), they seldom used them. A smaller percentage (64%) of nursing students overall had access to PDAs, but, of those, 25% reported frequent use of PDAs, 34.8% used them occasionally, and 52.2% used them only seldom for patient care questions. The selection criteria limit the ability to generalize the findings of this study to the whole field of nursing. A recommendation is to provide further education on information gathering from a database
Virtual focus group discussion
32 Frequent Internet users pulled from nursing informatics listserv, and Eastern University campus
Hermeneutical phenomenology approach

Some themes applicable to nursing and the use of the Internet for education include: Use of the Internet as a communication mode to connect patients and nurses with others with similar needs, ease of access, potential for developing internet addictions, avoidance of technological problems by planning well, be aware of computer literacy levels, and be aware of negative physical and psychosocial effects of Internet use
Instructor-led/text and interactive computer-based training
31 Nurses at Children’s Hospital Boston
Pretest/posttest control group quasi-experimental design and pilot study

Only nurses in the interactive computer-based training session had Posttest 2 scores that were significantly higher than their pretest scores (p < .000). The results suggest that the interactive approach had a greater effect on delivery of the content and in nurses’ retention of the content
Computer-mediated instruction for continuing education
500 health professionals
Online cross-sectional survey design and pilot testing

Greatest barriers identified for using computer-mediated instruction include: Lack of time (M = 1.60, SD = 1.10), lack of programs (M = 1.35, SD = 0.03), expense associated with taking continuing education programs (M = 1.26, SD = 1.06), lack of interaction with faculty/instructor (M = 1.24, SD = 1.04), lack of relevant topics for programs (M = 1.21, SD = 0.98), and lack of access to information about programs (M = 1.20, SD = 0.99). The strongest predictors of respondents’ ability to translate intention into action: Lack of programs (p = .01); lack of relevant topics for programs (p = .05); and lack of technical support for programs (p = .02)
Theory of planned behavior (TPB)
Hands-on continuing education class about the use of technology for continuing education
16 School nurses in Pennsylvania
Pre–post survey

Results indicated that 75% used the Internet to find information, 31% used MedlinePlus. There was an increase in use of the websites MedlinePlus and Health Information for the Consumer (website created by librarians at the Health Sciences Library System of the University of Pittsburgh) as well as an increase in the overall use of the Internet to locate health information after attendance at the class
A survey to determine perceived level of competence, the extent to which continuing nursing education (CNE) needs are being met, and the use of computers for CNE
559 Surveys from Registered nurses (RNs) in South Dakota from various areas
Descriptive comparative survey

One hundred nurses (17.9%) reported using computers for continuing education. The following reasons were identified for not using the computer for continuing education: Lack of knowledge about computer continuing nursing education programs, lack of access to a computer, lack of Internet access, lack of time, discomfort using computers, preference for books or other written material, continuing education not required, access to continuing education units through employer not needed, too costly, not interested, or not current
Online learning modules for advanced practice nurses
73 Registered nurses enrolled in graduate study or continuing education across the United States and internationally
Pretest, posttest quasi-experimental design

Paired sample t-test comparing pretest to posttest revealed significant increases in mean knowledge scores for participants in both modules: back pain (p < .0001) and dermatology (p < .0001). Participants indicated that modules were innovative, time saving, convenient, available, and economical. They liked the interactive case study approach, use of graphics, and the extensive links to other quality websites. Learners indicated they did not miss face-to-face interaction with colleagues during the course. Online learning is an effective method for providing continuing education to advanced practice nurses
Seven Principles for Good Practice in Undergraduate Education by Chickering & Gamson, 1987
Home-study computer-assisted program for pharmacokinetics
27 Advanced Practice Nurses (APNs) in Connecticut
Pretest–posttest measures of knowledge, self-efficacy, and satisfaction. Without control

Knowledge scores increased from a mean of 45.22 (SD = 15.70) pre-home CAI (computer assisted instruction) to 97.22 (SD = 7.97) post-home CAI (p < .0001) with an effect size of 3.31. Of the 27 participants in this study, 24 had post-home CAI knowledge scores of 100%. The overall mean self-efficacy score increased from 2.44 (SD = .64) pre-home CAI to 3.60 (SD=.54) post-home CAI (p < .0001) with an effect size of 1.81. The overall mean satisfaction score was 4.19 (SD = .56) on the 5-point scale. Computer-assisted instruction may be a feasible method for providing continuing education for APNs. Qualitative feedback was positive for this type of learning
Bandura’s social cognitive theory
Sources of information nurses use to inform practice
32 Articles
Integrative literature review

Two valuable lessons gained from this work include confirmation of the predominant use of informal, interactive sources of knowledge, and the influence of contextual factors such as role expectations and assumptions about information seeking to support practice
Asynchronous online tutorials
473 Registered nurses in California, 29% were school nurses
Descriptive comparative survey

No differences were seen in the tutorial completion rates among nurses who worked in hospital, community, and school settings (r = −.017; p = .552). 23% very satisfied and 49% somewhat satisfied with their computer capabilities at the time of enrollment
RehabNurse Listserv
76 Nurses that posted on RehabNurse-L in 2001 completed questionnaire and 41 interviewed
Grounded theory approach. Open-ended questionnaire and in-depth interviews.

96% shared information from the listserv with their coworkers, administrators, patients, families, and friends. Some ways in which the listserv assisted nurses were to find information about clinical concerns, quality measures, trends, products, staffing, regulations, education, and international issues. Participants described listserv attributes that they valued as collaboration, affirmation, and validation. Sample size was relatively small as the 76 respondents represent 25% of the postings on the listserv
Importance and barriers to continuing education for school nurses
15 Articles related to continuing education and school nurses
Literature review

Major issues identified: School nurses reported barriers such as time limits, family responsibilities, administration, hesitancy, lack of financial resources, and a lack of national school nurse education standards to support the need for continuing education. In the future, school nurses must have the capability and skills to utilize online continuing education, Web-based health resources, telehealth communication and online resources
Benner's novice to expert theory

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Information extracted from the articles included the theoretical framework used, the resources needed for a successful technology enhanced continuing education program, and the barriers to a successful technology enhanced continuing education program.

sec.title: Theoretical Framework
sec.p: Most of the reviewed studies did not identify a guiding theoretical framework. Of the three articles that identified a guiding theoretical framework, two used the diffusion of innovations theory. This theory predicts the likelihood that a new practice will be adopted by a particular culture (Rogers, 1962). This theory could be applicable in considering school nurses’ acceptance of the use of new technology for meeting their educational needs. For example, Bachman and Hsueh (2008) used the diffusion of innovations theory to identify characteristics of a program that are associated with participants perceiving that it is a better method of learning. The program must be convenient, satisfying, and have some advantage over an existing method. Another theory related to technology use in nurses is the technology acceptance model. This model focuses on factors that affect adoption of technology (Mazhar, 2010). Chen, Yang, Tang, Huang, and Yu (2008) utilized this theory and found that increased adoption of web-based learning techniques for continuing education was related to the nurse’s perception of the usefulness and ease of use of the technology. They also found that most nurses reported a high likelihood of using web-based learning.

sec.title: Increased Use of Technology
sec.p: Studies have indicated that nurses have an interest in learning through the use of technological resources. A literature review by Cobb (2004) found that the use of technology for continuing education is on the rise in the health care field. Adams (2009) found that school nurse respondents, who worked primarily in large school districts, used Internet sources more than textbooks. A study that evaluated the use of online continuing education for school nurses about diabetes management in children, reported an online course offered improvement in patient care (Bachman & Hsueh, 2008). Access to computers was not identified as a barrier and a course being online was seen as a strength of a program (Ellery, McDermott, & Ellery, 2007; Sweeney, Saarmann, Flagg, & Seidman, 2008). Charles and Mamary (2002) reported that 85% of nurse practitioners had access to the Internet, similar to findings in other studies. These studies were from the early 2000s, with the use of technology continuing to evolve and advance, it is likely that this number will continue to increase. Indeed, according to Adams’ (2009) study of school nurses, 80–96% of nurses had access to a computer at work and 70–80% of the nurses used the computer.

Another advantage to technology use is its ability to provide information that is “just in time.” Technology offers access to information at the time and place that it is needed. School nurses have indicated they need this just in time access, since they often cover a wide geographical area and care for many children with a variety of medical needs. Strategies were identified that were successful in providing technology-enhanced continuing education for school nurses. Several studies discussed the need for training to be interactive for the information to be retained (Bernardo & Stein, 2009; Charles & Mamary, 2002; Durkin, 2008; Huckstadt & Hayes, 2005; Neafsey, 1997). Technology can offer this interactivity through the innovative expansion of capabilities, including animation, hypertexts, video, and graphics. Using technology for continuing education and just-in-time learning lends itself to more self-directed learning. The nurse is able to choose what information they want and access it when they need that information. Additionally, the nurse is able to progress through the material at an individualized pace, which may lead to greater use of the educational materials (Neafsey, 1997).

sec.title: Barriers to Technology Use
sec.p: Most studies in this review identified at least some barriers to the use of technology for continuing education. The most common barriers cited were lack of time to find educational information (Atack, 2003; Cobb, 2004; Dee & Stanley, 2005; Gregg & Wozar, 2003; Hegge, Poers, Hendrickx, & Vinson, 2002; Vought-O’Sullivan, Meehan, Havice, & Pruitt, 2006), lack of knowledge about computers, technology, the Internet and specific programs (Atack, 2003; Charles & Mamary, 2002; Cobb, 2004; Dee & Stanley, 2005; Gregg & Wozar, 2003; Hegge et al., 2002; Huckstadt & Hayes, 2005; Neafsey, 1997), and lack of administrative support from school officials in using technology to access information and evidence for practice (Adams, 2009; Spenceley, O’Leary, Chizawsky, Ross, & Estabrooks, 2008).

Atack (2003), Dee and Stanley (2005), Gregg and Wozar (2003), and Hegge, Poers, Hendrickx, and Vinson (2002) found that some characteristics of computer use is problematic and presents a barrier. These characteristics include lack of access to a computer while away from the office and lack of remote access to databases such as the CINAHL and the National Library of Medicine (NLM), and lack of remote access to educational programs. While studies found that attending a professional conference is still the most common way for nurses to receive continuing education, authors discussed the need to look beyond conferences to provide education that is available at the time that it is needed and where it is needed (Charles & Mamary, 2002; Cobb, 2004; Dee & Stanley, 2005; Spenceley et al., 2008).

sec.title: Components of Successful Educational Programs
sec.p: Factors that could enhance the use of technology for education were identified in the articles reviewed. Different types of technology as well as different components of continuing education were identified as enhancing the educational experience. Dee and Stanley (2005) discussed nine types of health care resources that were used for education, including humans, books, journals, databases, handheld computers, Internet sites, electronic books and journals, teleconference or meetings, and drug representatives. The authors identified the three most frequently utilized health care resources as the computer, the Internet, and search engines. Components of continuing education that nurses found most helpful were also identified. Characteristics that should be considered in the development of technologically innovative educational programs include quick access (Atack, 2003; Dee & Stanley, 2005), the ability for the program to be completed in small pieces or “chunks,” and the flexibility to be able to interrupt and return to the program (Atack, 2003). Other characteristics of successful programs include convenience (Bachman & Hsueh, 2008; Bernardo & Stein, 2009), ease of use (Chen, Yang, Tang, Huang, & Yu, 2008; Dee & Stanley, 2005), reliability, and concise information (Dee & Stanley, 2005). The respondents in Dickerson and Feitshans’ (2003) study reported that the Internet offered up-to-date information that assisted with keeping current in professional practice and offered ease of access.

Several authors identified the importance of using interactive techniques rather than static presentation of information. This was done through the use of appealing and interesting information using graphics, links, case study format, animation, and offering interactive test questions (Durkin, 2008; Huckstadt & Hayes, 2005).

Another aspect to consider in creating successful educational programs is including ways for school nurses to have access to other school nurses for support, to offer opportunities to ask questions of experienced experts, and to provide opportunities to network with other nurses (Adams, 2009; Dee & Stanley, 2005; Dickerson & Feitshans, 2003; Huckstadt & Hayes, 2005). Listservs provide this opportunity. Listservs provide a sense of belonging with others of similar profession and offer a method to gain information from across the globe (Thompson & Penprase, 2004). They are especially helpful for school nurses since they tend to practice in isolation.

sec.title: Summary and Recommendations
sec.p: The indications from the literature are that school nurses, in general, are accepting of technology to enhance their learning, as long as it is perceived as both useful and easy to use. Use of technology is increasing among school nurses with upward of 80% using the computer at work. Technology-based education offers several advantages over traditional methods. It can provide access to information at the time and place that it is needed. This is a particularly useful characteristic for school nurse practice, which often takes place across buildings and settings. Technology-based educational offerings can include an interactive component that increases understanding and retention. Most importantly, technology affords the ability for learning to occur in a self-directed way. School nurses can choose what information they want, when they want it, and can progress through the material at an individualized pace. School nurses indicated that barriers to technology use include a lack of time to find educational information, lack of knowledge about computers, and lack of administrative support from school officials. Successful education programs are convenient, easy to use and quick to access, offer reliable and concise information that can be completed in small chunks, and offer the flexibility to be able to interrupt and return to the program.

School nurses require up-to-date and accurate information that is readily available during their workday. Through advancements in technology, this information can be provided utilizing a variety of means. Along with offering various informational and educational methods, it is imperative to offer clear and easy-to-follow training for the programs (Dee & Stanley, 2005) as well as adequate technological support to manage malfunctions and maintenance. Gregg and Wozar (2003) reported an increased use of the Internet for finding information after training was provided. The training included information on identifying and using quality and reliable medical information. While it is important to train nurses accessing the education program, it is also important to provide information to the school administrators on the importance of evidence-based practice and continuing education for school nurses. Nurses are more likely to access the available information and apply it to practice if they have the support of their administration (Dee & Stanley, 2005; Spenceley et al., 2008).

It is not a new idea to involve end users of programs in the design of the program. This holds true for school nurses as well. In order to increase the likelihood of the nurse accessing and using the educational tool, they need to be involved in the design (Spenceley et al., 2008). This involvement leads to a feeling that their voices are being heard and their needs are being met, and leads to a feeling of ownership. In addition, it is important to create an interactive program that makes learning interesting and enjoyable, holds the nurses’ attention, and assists with retention of the material. Many innovative technologies are being developed for use in the creation of educational tools to make them interactive, informative, and current.

School nurses, who often practice in rural, remote, and isolated school settings, must have the knowledge and skills to accurately assess, diagnose, identify outcomes, plan, implement, and evaluate children’s health issues. With the advancement of technology and the development of technological means to increase the availability of educational resources, school nurses have improved access to the information needed in order to benefit the school nurse, children, and community.

Mobile devices, such as smart phones and tablet computers, can be used to bring information to school nurses. A mobile information delivery device could serve as an “e-resource” providing clinical expertise, including guidelines, videos, and websites. This is an example of an innovative use of technology to reach nursing professionals who practice largely in isolation. In times of scarce resources, the use of technology has the potential to improve the school nurses’ access to information, which can increase knowledge, skills, and competency of the school nurses who provide school-based care to children with a variety of health-related conditions.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
